learning_outcomes.description: Recognise key theories and conventions of visual communication and how meaning is constructed through images.
Develop and iterate upon design ideas in response to design briefs using foundational design methods.
Implement foundational sketching techniques for design ideation and information visualisation.
Implement visual communication principles to develop, document, and showcase creative concepts in both digital and print media.
Identify and use appropriate digital software to communicate design outputs.
Construct vector and raster imagery to visually represent various types of information and articulate design ideas.
Critically evaluate visual communication approaches, taking into account purpose, audience, context, and medium.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 1: Visual Language and Communication Portfolio
assessments.category: Creative Production/ Exhibition, Portfolio, Product/ Design, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:  

This assignment invites you to create a Visual Language and Communication Portfolio that demonstrates your fluency in translating ideas, messages and information into visual representations, while applying what you learn about how meaning is constructed through visual communication. As you build your portfolio, you will experiment with designing visual identities, expressive posters, and data visualisations that communicate ideas to an audience. You will also develop practical skills in Adobe Illustrator while applying visual communication design methods with intention and creativity. The assessment encourages iterative making, experimentation and self-reflection. 

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The School of Architecture, Design and Planning uses Blackboard and Turnitin for assessment submission. Turnitin is accessed through the course Blackboard site. Turnitin also checks for plagiarism or instances where the original work of others is not appropriately acknowledged. Uploaded files must contain readable text and not be rasterised. Students are advised to commence assignment uploads with sufficient amount of time (consider possible technical problems with computers, internet speed, etc). After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission. To meet professional accreditation, public engagement and quality assurance obligations, digital copies of all course assessment items must be submitted in addition to any hard copy submission requirements specified in individual Course / Studio Outlines. Any physical models should be photographed and a minimum of two photographs describing the complete and full model must be included in the digital submission.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2: Visual Storytelling and Influential Imagery Portfolio
assessments.category: Creative Production/ Exhibition, Portfolio, Product/ Design, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The Visual Storytelling and Influential Imagery Portfolio offers you an opportunity to creatively explore how designers create and edit images, including photographs, to translate ideas, tell stories and shape meaning. As you build your portfolio, you will creatively explore how to translate design ideas into expressive visual representations that communicate speculative narratives or design interventions. 

Through guided workshops, you will use foundational design methods to plan, iterate, and refine your image-based compositions, while engaging critically with the ways visual media can represent place, identity, and emotion. You will develop practical skills in Adobe Photoshop and explore optional AI-assisted tools to manipulate and generate imagery.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 3: Visual Systems and Design Proposal
assessments.category: Creative Production/ Exhibition, Portfolio, Poster, Product/ Design, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:  

This assignment challenges students to design and showcase a suite of interconnected visual communication outputs in response to a project brief, developing your capabilities in designing visuals with audience, context, space, time and clear intentions in mind. 

Students will be introduced to an overarching project brief and then to a series of related design tasks during weekly in-class workshops and will have the opportunity to apply what you learn about visual identity systems, effective layouts, engaging promotional touch points and supportive wayfinding systems. Students will compile each design output into a professional, cohesive design proposal, including designs intended for both digital and print outputs. 

As you work through the project, you will develop practical skills in Adobe InDesign, while selecting to use Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop depending on the task.
